Award.AwardTitle: UBM-Group: Collaborative Research on the Arthropod Way of Life (CRAWL): Interdisciplinary Training in Mathematical Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at East Tennessee State University provides opportunities for Students to gain skills in biology and math through full participation in the research process. A major component of the Collaborative Research on the Arthropod Way of Life CRAWL program is long-term immersion in a research project, involving each student in every stage of the scientific process. Major emphases are on: (1) the hypothetico-deductive approach to problem-solving, (2) rigorous experimental design developed by the entire team, thus ensuring a truly integrative approach, (3) introduction to critical thinking and the application of mathematical and biological skills via workshops, (4) "on-the-job" learning of critical skills for data collection, data management, statistical analyses, and mathematical modeling, (5) dissemination of results at both the local and national levels, (6) undergoing the publication process, including creation of publication-quality graphs & tables, scientific writing, and responding to reviewer critiques. The PIs of the project have developed projects that address fundamental questions in the areas of spatiotemporal dynamics of intraspecific interactions (aggression in spiders and flies, communication in honey bees) and the neurohormonal underpinnings and ecological implications of these behaviors. Analytical approaches include time-series analyses, spatial analyses, agent-based modeling, graph theoretic analyses, logistic regression modeling, and diffusion-based mathematical models. With its inter-connected biological and mathematical themes, joint mentorship, and team approach, CRAWL is a model for efficiently integrating undergraduates into established research programs.

The Undergraduate Biomathematics Program supported by NSF at the East Tennessee State Unvisersity provides opportunities to engage undergraduates in meaningful interdisciplinary research experiences. The CRAWL program aims to generate a research culture in biology and math at ETSU by building an infrastructure that will ensure its sustainability. Critical to its success, the excitement of the discovery process must be translated into classroom and teaching laboratory experiences for students not directly supported by the program. The CRAWL program is intended to have a synergistic effect on the overall curriculum at ETSU as projects and results are incorporated as modules into upper division math and biology courses. In addition, several of the research projects may be adapted as teaching laboratories. CRAWL students have the opportunity to impact other underrepresented students at the university by providing guest lectures and presentations in both introductory and upper level courses. CRAWL students are selected and recruited from under-represented groups in the Southern Appalachian region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this grant, professors from the Departments of Biological Sciences and Mathematics and Statistics at East Tennessee State University (ETSU) worked  with undergraduate students each year and placed them in long-term (summer plus fall and spring semesters) research projects in mathematical/quantitative biology. Integrated research teams (Math and Biology students together with Math and Biology mentors) tackled significant questions at the interface of the two disciplines. The students were actively involved in all phases of the projects from conception to completion, culminating in presentations and manuscript submission. Part of our mission was to transform our undergraduate students from being traditional classroom students into active scientists and mathematicians. Our research projects covered a wide range of biological/mathematical areas but were unified and strengthened by focusing on related biological questions in three arthropod model systems (social spiders, flesh flies, and honey bees). Accordingly, our project was entitled "Collaborative Research on the Arthropod Way of Life" or CRAWL. This common focus was further enhanced by using mathematical/statistical approaches that were applicable to all three systems. It was imperative for the success of our program that the students' learning gains and experiences be translated into high-profile accomplishments -- publications and professional presentations. The first of our major goals was to inspire our students to pursue careers in the STEM areas. We believe that our emphasis on participation at all levels of the process provided our students not only with excellent technical preparation but also with the sense of achievement and of being a part of the community of scholars, thus giving them confidence to go to the next level. Our second major goal was to create an infrastructure for long-term, sustainable undergraduate research in quantitative biology at our University. We hope to develop a thriving culture of undergraduate research by creating a reward structure that benefits both students and professors. The CRAWL program included substantial summer support for student research as well as supplemental support during the academic year, thus enabling students to maintain long-term continuity with their projects. This approach removed a major barrier to sustained progress in our undergraduate research program.

Over the course of the grant, we achieved noteworthy progress in both the biological/experimental and the mathematical/analytical aspects of each of the projects. In concert with our efforts to encourage and prepare our students for success in STEM careers, we published seven articles in professional journals, another was submitted, and three more are in preparation. We also made 26 professional presentations in national/international and regional professional meetings. Work derived from this grant contributed directly to two undergraduate Honor's Theses and inspired a Master’s Thesis.

In the fly group, we discovered an age-related development of aggressive behaviors in male flesh flies that, surprisingly, is accompanied by a vast reorganization of the entire behavioral repertoire. This finding has implications for other studies of animal aggression. In the honey bee group, we found that forager bees pay attention to a number of different factors in the decision where to locate the “dance floor,” the location where foragers recruit their nestmates to profitable food sources. These results have the potential of further increasing our understanding of foraging behavior in this agriculturally critical organism. In the spider group, we discovered mechanisms used by social spiders to maximize their prey capture.
